bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 9, 1876

div1.p: Reed teases Emilie Lawrence that his finger was injured by her. He describes cases of measles at the base.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, March 9, 1876
div1.opener:
Am expec-
ting a dar-
ling little
letter from
you soon.
W.
Willets Point, N.Y.H.
March 9th 76.
My own, sweet Emilie;
div1.p:
If you
find some difficulty in de-
ciphiring this letter, you must
excuse it on account of a
lame finger- You will perhaps
remember that when you
playfully struck me with
the pencil which you were using
in erasing the writing in
your French Grammar, that
I told you that such hard
blows might give rise to
a lame hand- Although, I
did not really think so at the time,
yet either that blow on
my Index finger, or something
else has given rise to what
I, yesterday, feared would
turn out to be a felon- I
am glad to inform my little
darling that my finger is
very much better, to-day, & al-
though I can not hold my pen
with it, to much advantage,
yet I do not anticipate any
further trouble. Now would
you not have been very sorry
to learn that I was so sore-
ly wounded? And you won't
hit me so hard, again; will
you, my precious? No! I know
you will not-

When I reached my Post, I found
everybody very glad to see
me back & was accorded
a very kind welcome- Sev-
eral of the officers inquired
of the “little Carolina beauty”,
& were anxious to know
with what success I had
met- one or two went so far
as to say, that they believed
I had got married & had
brought my wife as far as
Flushing-etc. etc- I found a
good many on the sick list &
now have a half dozen cases
of measles just developed-
So that I am not afraid of
having nothing to do, for some
time to come. I must not forget
to tell you that I met Pa, at the Steam-
er, last Saturday, & spoke to
him about “H. H. Norman, M.D.”
He said that he knew him
several years, ago: that, at
that time, he was a very
clever, nice gentleman; that
in speaking of young ladies,
in his presence, on one oc-
cassion, he (Pa) invited him
to visit Murfreesboro; that
there were some very intel-
ligent & pleasant young
ladies in town, at the same time,
mentioning the names of
several young ladies of Mur-
freesboro, your name among
the rest. He can't imagine why
Dr. Norman should only rem-
ember your name, never
having seen your- of course,
if he had once seen you, my
little love, then it would be
very plain that he should
remember you alone- I cau-
tioned Pa not to give you to any
one else, & I don't think he
will. Please pardon this scratch,
as I am not able, physically,
to write more-
div1.closer:
Good-bye and
believe me, as ever, your fond
& devoted lover,
Walter.
